pages.text: Charniodiscus concentricus comes from the late Ediacaran, with fossils found across all Edicaran Avalon, White Sea and Nama Assemblages. It is a leaf-like petalonamid lifeform, and can be found in from deep to shallow waters, growing up to 22 cm in height, and possibly partook in filter feeding from the surrounding water.

Charniodiscus is currently the only known petalonamae to have the unique ability to fold all its branches separately from each other, allowing it to 'catch' nutrients in the water. The generic names derives from the genus name of 'Charnia', a similar looking petalonamae; and the Latin word 'discus', to mean 'disc'. The specific name 'concentricus' is a Latin word, referring to the appearance of the holdfast.
